access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient must use a generic third-party release authorization form, writing their own name as the recipient, with no guidance that this is a valid use case.

red_flags: Form structured exclusively for third-party release with no patient self-access pathway or guidance
Ambiguous witness signature line may deter patients completing the form at home
Form dated 2014 — over 11 years old and may not reflect current regulatory requirements
Internal document-management codes visible on patient-facing form
bright_spots: Built-in Notice of Revocation section eliminates need for a separate revocation form
Granular record-type selection with nine categories plus Complete Record option
Email submission channel available via release@columbusch.com

findability.rationale: Rubric level 3: requires moderate effort — form found via web search but not linked from the main patient-facing website; patient forms page mentions the form without providing a download link.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Rubric level 2: primarily a paper workflow — zero fillable fields require printing and handwriting; email submission is available but the form itself offers no digital interaction.

content_design.rationale: Rubric level 3: adequate but has notable problems — concise single-page layout with logical flow, but includes unexplained jargon ('H & P'), internal filing codes, no instructions, and dense formatting.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Rubric level 2: patient self-access is an afterthought — form is designed entirely for third-party release with no dedicated patient access pathway, no right-of-access language, and no guidance for patients requesting their own records.

compliance.rationale: Rubric level 3: some requirements that may go beyond what the law requires — ambiguous witness line could create a barrier, no mention of patient access rights under HIPAA, though revocation rights and non-retaliation language are appropriately included.

overall.summary: Columbus Community Hospital provides a minimally functional but outdated records request process built around a generic third-party release form with no dedicated patient self-access pathway.
